description:
Bicyclus anynana, commonly known as the Squinting Bush Brown, is a species of butterfly belonging to the family Nymphalidae. It is native to sub-Saharan Africa, primarily found in regions such as South Africa, Mozambique, and Tanzania.

Bicyclus anynana is a medium-sized butterfly with a wingspan of approximately 50-60 millimeters. The upper surface of its wings is predominantly brown in color, with distinct eyespots on the hindwings. The underside of the wings is mottled, which helps the butterfly camouflage itself when at rest.

This species is known for its remarkable ability to display phenotypic plasticity, where the appearance of the butterfly can vary depending on environmental cues. For example, individuals that develop during the dry season tend to have more pronounced eyespots on their wings, while those that develop during the wet season exhibit less pronounced eyespots.

Bicyclus anynana is widely studied in the field of evolutionary biology, particularly in the context of understanding the mechanisms behind phenotypic plasticity and the evolution of wing patterns. Its ease of rearing in laboratory conditions has made it a valuable model organism for research on developmental genetics, sexual selection, and the evolution of adaptive traits.
